properties.descrip: When turning right from South Mall on to the cycle track there is a pole for the pedestrian crossing. This makes it very difficult to turn right at anything other than slow speeds. This is a especially a problem if the traffic behind the cyclists is not expecting the cyclist to slow down.

The cycle track which is raised and off the road quickly merges the cyclist with the road traffic which are potentially moving into the same area to make a left turn into the retail park. Very dangerous.
There is a traffic light pole right in the middle of cycle track.
Cracked paving slabs due to illegal parking

Not enough room for vehicular traffic in road lane so cars stacked at the lights typically occupy 30-50% of the right hand side of the bike lane. Insufficient room to pass forces people cycling to dismount and walk bicycle on footpath
The cycle lane regularly floods here. The drains are not cleared and a layer of mud and debris now covers around half of the northbound cycle lane. It is a slip hazard.

The shared cycle+walking path ends just before the St. Vincents bridge. There is a collision with risk pedestrians crossing the bridge and there is also a collision risk with cyclists merging with vehicles on the road.
There is a step up to the bridge here which forces people cycling to dismount if crossing the bridge
Cycle lane ends just after a sharp turn. No indication as to what road user (cyclist or driver) has right of way.

Automatic sensor didn't register my bike - waited for a good 4 or 5 minutes. No cars behind me to trip sensor. Lanes of traffic from the east, west, and south, were all given green lights at least twice.
As the cycle lane goes left around the parking spaces, it is a very tight 'chicane' requiring the cyclist to abruptly slow down if you are unfamiliar with this cycle lane.
There are car parking spaces on the outside of this cycle lane which means it is very easy for a door to open as a cyclist passes and there is no room to take emergency action.
When cars are parked in the parking bay, parts of the vehicle can enter the cycle lane, such as a wheel or front bumper, making what is already a narrow cycle lane even narrower.

A downhill slope on the western end of Castle Road leads to a non-obvious STOP at the Convent Road-Blackrock road junction. The junction priority is no longer with the obvious straight through road, and there is no STOP line on the road. The downhill slope would also encourage cyclists to pick up speed as they approach the junction.
Traffic lights sensors on Capwell road at the Capwell road-South Douglas road junction do not detect cyclists. They only activate when a larger vehicle arrives.

Cycling from Pouladuff Rd to turn left for Forge Hill Rd, the road is significantly narrower here with no option to safely dismount on the steep ascent at this point as there's no footpath until you reach the flat bit after the slope. A high number of lorries and other large vehicles pass here frequently. Cycling the opposite direction, from Forge Hill to Pouldaduff Rd, there is a steep ascent and a dangerous junction where it is difficult to see oncoming traffic from the right-hand side.
The automatic sensor very often does not detect bikes. In fact, the bike lane does not take the cyclist of the sensor on the road, and therefore is reliant on a car triggering the sensor.

Turning left from Grattan Street on to the cycle lane on Liberty Street takes you directly onto a pavement around a partially blind corner. Pedestrians are not given any warning that cyclists may be mounting the pavement here, nor are they directed to stand at a particular place when waiting at the crossing.

Westbound cycle lane going to Ballincollig ends just before the turn off to Inchaggin Lane. People cycling have to cross a busy road with no assistance. Cars not expecting people to be pushing bikes across the road at this location.
Cycle lane closed due to building collapse. No attempt made to provide temporary cycle lane.
Not enough of a space provided between cycle lane and parked cars. Have witnessed several people knocked off their bikes here to due to car doors being opened without checking first. Poor design.
There are several ESB poles in the cycle lane along Skehard Rd as you travel inbound.

When approach this junction from Old Station Road, it is difficult to see how a cyclist is supposed to join the cycle lane on the west side of Anglesea Street.

Making a left turn the cyclist will have to slow considerably, which, given there is likely traffic behind the cyclist this could be a dangerous manoeuvre.

Turning right, there is a traffic island in the middle of the road which will allow the cyclist to wait, however, again requires the cyclist to slow. If the cyclist avoids the island and goes straight for the cycle lane, on coming traffic is unlikely to expect this.

If turning right from Merchant's Quay on to the cycle lane at Parnell Place, it is not clear whether the cyclists is supposed to use the pedestrian crossing.The green man shows, but no green bike. Is this a shared crossing or not? Furthermore, the road signage says no right turn except buses.

The is a No Left Turn sign here, however, there is a Left Turn for cyclists as this is where the cycle lane is. 

Or are cyclists not supposed to turn left here, and the cycle lane is only for those coming from Fenns Quay?
Traffic light does not detect bikes.
Poor surface and two manholes both on the cycling lane. Drivers don't notice this and usually abuse me when I take primary position to avoid them.

Closest bike parking is outside of Nano Nagle, no other facilities heading towards Langford Row. With the number of businesses (pubs, restaurants, etc.) in this zone, some people lock their bikes to the railings outside St John's Mews, which obstructs the footpath. There's a double yellow line at this point, so bike parking would not result in losing parking spaces (although people park illegally here all the time!)

There's car parking right outside businesses here but no facilities to lock bikes. Closest pole to lock a bike to is on corner with South Mall. If people on cars can park right outside Joyce's why not people on bikes?
Dangerous junction if person cycling is going straight ahead and car going in the same direction turns on Cornmarket Street. I've had 2 near misses here.

There is no bike parking in this part of the community centre (where the scout hall, community centre hall, creche, tennis club are). There are 30 spaces for cars in this area (without counting those for blue badge holders) and no bike racks, closest one is down the park on the Boreenmanna side of the park.

In the east bound cycle lane, when a bus at the bus stop it forces the cyclist into traffic, and then if the cyclist wishes to continue using the cycle lane, almost immediately the cyclist has to pull in front of the bus to get onto the cycle lane. There is too much going on in a short amount of time that forces the cyclist into a number of unsafe road positions and movements.

When travelling westbound - there is a pinch point that caused by the pavement which narrows the road. Given this is soon after the junction on Old Station Road, it is common to have vehicles behind the cyclist, who often try and overtake at this point, and often do not give the cyclist enough room as the driver is unaware of the narrowing road.

The cars parked left of the cycle lane often drive forwards into the space, this means to get out they have to reverse across the cycle lane, just after a narrow road with some blind spots. Cars can easily back out into a cyclist in the cycle lane. Essentially, it is a lot safer for the cyclist not to use the cycle lane.
Cyclist waiting to turn right have to wait in the cycle lane - this blocks cyclist continuing straight on, and potentially forcing them on to the pedestrian area of the pavement.
There is no cycle parking to service this part of the retail park. Even Halfords,a shop that sells bikes and cycling equipment, does not provide one.
Traffic lights at this very busy junction leaving the shopping centre do not detect bikes at all.
All three sets of lights at this junction do not detect cyclists whatsoever.
Bus lane traffic lights and regular traffic lights do not detect cyclists at the Link Rd-Skehard Rd junction turnoff.
Kissing Gate which is restrictive to those using wheelchairs, double buggies, bike trailers, cargobikes or handcycles

No kerbdrop. Cyclists are forced to cycle up the pathway or push the bike up the pathway, especially in non-traditional bikes that cannot take being bumped down off the kerb. A kerb drop would allow cyclist to cycle legally up the hill to the entrance to the estate further up and merge with the greenway there.
Kissing Gates. Makes transition through the gates impossible for those in wheelchairs, cargobikes, handcycles and larger buggies. Particularly ableist at a hospital.
Sign Saying "No Right Turn" but only way onto contra flow cycle lane is to turn right. Should have a "Except Cyclists" added to the sign
"No Right Turn" sign but this is the only way onto the contraflow cycle lane from Donavan's Road. Would be best to add "Except Cyclists" to this sign

Exiting the bridge there is a narrow kerbdrop which is about 40cm wide. This is too narrow for both bicycles or wheelchairs/buggies to alight safely. This should be extended to make it safer to exit the bridge.

Cars park to close to the drop down from the bridge to safely alight, a problem with a bicycle or a wheelchair/buggy. This immediate area should have permanent bollards and hashed markings indicating no parking at any time.
Poor rutted surface at the start of the bridge which is a hazzard
No Cycle Parking ANYWHERE in the area!
Poor surface in Bus/cycle lane has forced me to take the lane as too dangerous in buslane
Cycle lane with no protection. Hook Turn at speed by motorised vehicles. Radial should be narrowed to slow motorised traffic.

Not possible to transition from the Borreenmanna Road to the unofficial Quietway that leads to the Old Blackrock Road safely. Ped Crossing should become Toucan and raised. Speed should be lowered to 30k/h in light of school access.
Rat Run Entry Point. Should be closed to through traffic
Large Bollards with wide footprint means cyclist have to take awkward maneuver to get onto cycle lane. Should be moved to avoid hazard to cyclists and pedestrians
Beg Button Toucan. Should be Pedestrian/Cyclist Priority

Inbound Cycling Lane abruptly goes onto footpath before a tight left hand corner and the abruptly ends up on the footpath. Real concern that a cyclist wouldn't notice this and end up cycling off curb and into traffic.

Cycling lane ends abruptly at roundabout and if the cyclist intends to take the 3rd exit at the roundabout they have to cross 4 lanes of traffic at a very slow speed. No crossing at roundabout so a cyclist merging from the cycling path (at zero to low speed) is not expected by traffic.

The cycle lane starts from an area of the pavement, which separates parking from the main road. When no car is parked in the parking spot, and in the dark, it is very difficult to see the pavement, and a cyclist can easily look to join the cycle lane no realising the kerb is in the way. Very dangerous design.
The cycle lane by Centra are almost always blocked. Should be segregated with bollards
Cycle lane ends abruptly and dangerously; light post is placed in the middle of cycle lane
Cycle lane is going onto footpath and then cyclist is forced to stop to cross the car offramp
Cycle lane at bus stop causes dangerous interactions between cyclists and waiting bus users
Westbound cycle lane ends without reason
Missing cycle for left-hand turn onto Harbour View
Sensor not registering bikes leaving from Cross Douglas Road onto Douglas Road
Cycle lane Northbound is regularly crossed into as the road width ad the bend is narrow. Number of attempts at overtaking at this bend
